intro: Ipomopsis crebrifolia, commonly known as the common ipomopsis, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from blue to purple. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils in open habitats such as meadows and slopes. It has hairy stems and leaves that are often glandular, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits containing numerous seeds. Ipomopsis crebrifolia is often found in arid or semi-arid environments and is adapted to thrive in full sun.
